item.title: Makiivka: Russia points fingers after deadliest Ukraine attack
item.description: The deaths of dozens of Russian soldiers at Makiivka in Ukraine prompt recriminations in Russia.

item.title: Russia plans to 'exhaust' Ukraine with prolonged attacks - Zelensky
item.description: Ukraine's president says Moscow aims to exhaust his country with a prolonged wave of drone strikes.

item.title: Russians attack Zaporizhzhia Oblast, one civil infrastructure facility on fire, civilian injured
item.description: On the evening of 3 January, the Russian invaders struck the outskirts of Zaporizhzhia with missiles. One person was injured as a result of the attack, and a fire broke out at a civilian infrastructure facility.

item.title: Explosions heard in Rostov and Kursk
item.description: On 3 January, residents and eyewitnesses reported the sounds of explosions in the Russian cities of Rostov-on-Don and Kursk. Source: Radio Liberty Russia, videos from local Russian Telegram channels Details: In particular, residents are publishing photos and videos showing explosions in Russian cities.

item.title: Zelenskyy on destruction of Altaïr in Druzhkivka: This is another confession of the terrorist state
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy reacted to the destruction of the Altaïr ice arena in Druzhkivka, Donetsk Oblast by the Russian occupiers; the arena was used for the collection and distribution of humanitarian aid.

item.title: Zelenskyy: Russia’s attempted offensive must become its final failure
item.description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy, the President of Ukraine, believes that the Russian government will deploy all Russian forces in order to try to change the outcome of the war and postpone their defeat. Source: Zelenskyy's video address on 3 January Quote: "We started this year with what Ukraine needs most right now - on the eve of new mobilisation processes being prepared by the terrorist state.

item.title: AEW&C aircraft that helps in targeting arrived in Belarus from Russia
item.description: An Il-76 A-50U aircraft, designed to track air and surface targets, arrived at the Machulishchy airfield in Belarus from Russia. Source: Belaruski Hajun [an independent Belarusian military monitoring media outlet] Quote: "At 21:25, an Il-76 A-50U AEW&C [airborne early warning and control - ed.

item.title: Ukraine Palace of Arts shares video of Russian rocket strike that damaged building
item.description: The Ukraine National Palace of Arts, a theatre, concert hall and official event venue, has posted a video filmed by surveillance cameras during a missile strike on the centre of Kyiv on 31 December which damaged the building.

item.title: Erdoğan to speak to Putin and Zelenskyy on Wednesday
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan plans to hold telephone conversations with his Ukrainian and Russian counterparts, Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Vladimir Putin, on Wednesday. This was announced on the NTV channel on Tuesday by Ibrahim Kalin, the advisor to the Turkish president, European Pravda reports.

item.title: Russian medics flee from occupied Melitopol
item.description: Russian medics are following in the wake of the collaborators and fleeing from the occupied city of Melitopol in Zaporizhzhia Oblast. Source: Ivan Fedorov, the mayor of Melitopol, on Telegram Quote: "The Melitopol city hospital was practically the last hospital in temporarily occupied Zaporizhzhia Oblast that was still providing medical care to civilians, but it has now been almost a month since the occupiers started bringing wounded and sick soldiers there, and there is less and less space for civilians in the hospital.

item.title: Russian invader repeats rumours about full mobilisation in Russia in new intercepted call
item.description: In a phone call that was recently recorded by Defence Intelligence of the Ministry of Defence of Ukraine, a Russian soldier says there are rumours of a full mobilisation in Russia and describes the Russian command instructing troops to "attack" with minimal forces.

item.title: Zelenskyy thanked Norway's Prime Minister for energy support of Ukraine
Russians marching over corpses: Ukrainian Army Commander-in-Chief reports on situation at front
item.description: Valerii Zaluzhnyi, the Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, spoke with Mark Milley, the chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, on the phone for the first time this year on 3 January 2023, and reported on the situation at the front.

item.title: Half a million Ukrainian school-age children are currently living abroad
item.description: As of the beginning of January 2023, there are about 500,000 Ukrainian children of school age living abroad. At the beginning of the academic year [1 September - ed.], there were 488,000. This was announced by Serhii Shkarlet, the Minister of Education and Science of Ukraine, on the 24/7 national newscast.

item.title: Metal detectors and scanners in public spaces, Cabinet of Ministers plans to strengthen security in Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal has announced that metal detectors and scanners will be installed in public spaces for enhanced security of the citizens. Source: Shmyhal at a governmental meeting Quote: "In 2023, we will be actively forging the security infrastructure in our country.

item.title: Ukrainian forces hit two Russian command posts, occupiers attack near Bakhmut – General Staff report
item.description: Over the past 24 hours, units of the Armed Forces of Ukraine hit two command posts of Russians; the invaders did not quit attempting to reach the administrative border of Donetsk Oblast and tried to conduct offensive operations on the Bakhmut front Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine Details: Aviation of Ukraine's defence forces carried out four strikes on clusters of Russian military personnel, weapons and equipment.

item.title: Kreminna-Svatove highway under fire control of Armed Forces of Ukraine
item.description: Serhiy Haidai, the head of Luhansk Oblast, has said that the Kreminna-Svatove highway is under the fire control of the Ukrainian Defenders and now the logistics of the Russian invaders have become much more complicated.

item.title: Zelenskyy discussed defenсe cooperation with UK Prime Minister
Russians hit trolleybus in Kherson
item.description: Russian soldiers have attacked Khersonelectrotrans, a state-owned regional utility company, in the city of Kherson, hitting one of trolleybuses and an administrative building. Source: press service of Kherson City State Council quoting Halyna Luhova, Head of Kherson City Military Administration Details: A projectile hit one of trolleybuses.

item.title: Russia keeps nuclear weapons carriers in Crimea
item.description: The Defence Intelligence of Ukraine has said that Russia keeps its ground-based, air-launched and sea-based carriers of nuclear weapons in temporarily occupied Crimea. Source: Ukrinform news agency, quoting Andrii Cherniak, representative of the Defence Intelligence Quote: "The Defence Intelligence sees that carriers of nuclear weapons that are ground-based, air-launched and sea-based are located in the territory of temporarily occupied Crimea at the moment.

item.title: Ukrainian Air Force explains why they don’t shoot down Shahed UAVs flying along Dnipro
item.description: The Russian forces most often launch Iranian-made kamikaze drones at night along the Dnipro riverbed, because this way, it is harder to detect the UAVs with radar. Source: Yurii Ihnat, spokesman for the Ukrainian Air Force, on the air of Ukrainian Radio Details: When asked why the air defence does not shoot down UAVs moving along the Dnipro River, the Air Force spokesman noted: Quote: "Because they become less visible on radar the closer they press to the ground.

item.title: Russian forces blow up power plant during retreat from Beryslav, Kherson Oblast
item.description: Russian troops have blown up a power plant during their retreat from Beryslav, Kherson Oblast, in November. Source: Oleksii Reznikov, Ukrainian Minister of Defence, on Twitter Quote: "In Beryslav (Kherson region), Russians retreated and intentionally blew up a power plant.

item.title: Russian forces hit Kramatorsk, one person wounded
item.description: Russian forces attacked the city of Kramatorsk in Donetsk Oblast on the afternoon of 3 January, wounding one person. Source: Oleksandr Honcharenko, Mayor of Kramatorsk, on Facebook Quote from Honcharenko: "Kramatorsk is under attack.

item.title: "It is immoral to hide behind neutrality": Ukraine’s Foreign Minister invites IOC Head to Druzhkivka, Donetsk Oblast
item.description: Dmytro Kuleba, Minister for Foreign Affairs of Ukraine, invites the International Olympic Committee (IOC) President, Thomas Bach, and other sports officials to the city of Druzhkivka, Donetsk Oblast, to see the consequences of Russia's attacks on Ukrainian athletes.

item.title: Zelenskyy and Dutch Prime Minister discussed assistance for Ukraine
Former head of Russian railway subsidiary detained in Kherson
item.description: The Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) has reported that the former head of a Russian railway subsidiary in the city of Kherson, who helped to transfer Russian military convoys to Ukraine, has been arrested.

item.title: Car runs over Russian explosives in Kherson Oblast, 2 people killed
item.description: Two people have been killed following a car hitting an explosive left by the Russians in the Beryslav district of Kherson Oblast. Source: Yaroslav Yanushevych, Head of Kherson Oblast Military Administration, on Telegram Quote from Yanushevych: "A car carrying civilians hit Russian explosives at the exit from Mala Oleksandrivka [Kherson Oblast].

item.title: Russian forces hit residential area in Kurakhove, Donetsk Oblast, killing 1 person and wounding 2 others
item.description: Russian troops attacked a residential area in the city of Kurakhove, Donetsk Oblast, on the morning of 3 January, hitting a multi-storey building, damaging a water supply facility, killing one person and wounding two others.

item.title: Strangled, beaten and tasered: Russian torture chamber discovered in Mykolaiv Oblast
item.description: Law enforcement officers have discovered another torture chamber in Mykolaiv Oblast which the occupiers had set up in the village of Oleksandrivka. Source: Prosecutor's Office in Mykolaiv Oblast on Facebook; Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) on Telegram Quote from the Prosecutor's Office: "According to the investigation, representatives of the aggressor country seized houses in the village and illegally held and brutally tortured local residents who refused to cooperate with the enemy.

item.title: Zelenskyy calls meeting of Staff of Supreme Commander-in-Chief and hears reports
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy held a regular meeting of the Supreme Commander-in-Chief's Staff on Tuesday, 3 January. Source: Office of the President of Ukraine Details: It is reported that at the meeting, a report was heard on the operational situation on the main frontlines from Valerii Zaluzhnyi, Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

item.title: Russian missiles damage residential buildings and wound man in Kramatorsk, Donetsk Oblast
item.description: 34 private houses and eight apartment buildings have been damaged and one person wounded following a Russian missile strike on Kramatorsk, Donetsk Oblast, late in the evening on 2 January. Source: Kramatorsk City Council, quoting Oleksandr Honcharenko, Mayor of Kramatorsk; Pavlo Kyrylenko, Head of Donetsk Oblast Military Administration Quote from Honcharenko: "Aftermath of the night missile attack on Kramatorsk: 34 private houses and eight apartment buildings have been damaged.

item.title: Russia prepares new offensive actions, may attack from north or east
item.description: Russia is not planning to end the war against Ukraine but will continue offensive operations on various fronts. Source: Website of the Main Intelligence Directorate of the Ukrainian Ministry of Defence, quoting Andrii Cherniak, a representative from Defence Intelligence, Quote from Cherniak: "According to Ukrainian military intelligence estimates, the Russians will try to continue conducting offensive operations next year.

item.title: Photos released of ice rink in Druzhkivka destroyed by Russian attack
item.description: A missile attack conducted by the Russians on 2 January destroyed the ice rink and damaged the buildings of the MAN Hotel, the bus station, a church, a residential building and outbuildings in the city of Druzhkivka.

item.title: Thanks to warm weather, all Ukraine will have power until lunchtime
item.description: Due to the warm weather, power consumption in Ukraine has decreased, and power plants are producing enough electricity to cover the load, so consumption restrictions shall not be applied until 14:00. Source: Ukrenergo's press service on Telegram [Ukrenergo is Ukraine's National Power Company and a Transmission System Operator (TSO)].

item.title: I'm not asking your permission. Stories of three Ukrainian warriors who died before they were 21
Ukraine’s Security Service issues notices of suspicion to 2 Russian commanders for attacking civilian facilities
item.description: The Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) has issued the first notices of suspicion for the shelling of civilian facilities in Ukraine to Colonel General Sergei Kobylash, commander of the Russian Air Force's Long-Range Aerospace Forces, and Admiral Igor Osipov, the former Commander of the Russian Black Sea Fleet [a notice of suspicion is an important initial stage of a pre-trial investigation under Ukrainian criminal procedure law - ed.

item.title: It is too early to talk about liberation of Velykyi Potomkin Island in Kherson Oblast
item.description: The Ukrainian military has raised the national flag on the island of Velykyi Potomkin in Kherson Oblast, but it is still too early to talk about the liberation of the island. Source: Natalia Humeniuk, Head of the United Press Center of the Operational Command Pivden (South) on the air of the national 24/7 joint newscast Quote from Humeniuk: "The raising of the flag is a signal to the enemy that we are working, that the land is ours, and that this is all Ukraine.

item.title: Warsaw calls Russian propaganda about "Polish mercenaries" in Ukraine a lie
item.description: Russian propaganda continues to promote lies about the alleged mass participation and huge losses among "Polish mercenaries" in the war in Ukraine. Source: European Pravda, quoting Stanislav Zharin, the government's Commissioner for the Security of Poland's Information Space "This topic is a constant element used in propaganda efforts in the Russian information space aimed at the Russian public," he wrote.

item.title: French journalists come under missile attack during live broadcast from Kramatorsk
item.description: French journalists covering the events in Ukraine filmed the missile attack in Kramatorsk on 2 January during a live broadcast in the studio. Source: European Pravda Paul Gasnier, Héloïse Grégoire and Théo Palfray are staying in the east of Ukraine and have been joining the air of TF1-TMC from Kramatorsk.

item.title: Russia deploys six ships on combat duty in the Black Sea
item.description: The Russian command has sent up to six warships to the Black Sea, while another is on duty in the Sea of Azov. Source: Ukraine's Naval Forces on Facebook Details: According to the Navy, up to six Russian ships are on combat duty in the Black Sea.

item.title: Russians hit Kherson Oblast 79 times, killing 2 people
item.description: Two people were killed and nine were injured as a result of Russian attacks on Kherson Oblast on 2 January. Source: Yaroslav Yanushevych, Head of Kherson Oblast Military Administration, on Telegram Quote from Yanushevych: "The Russian occupiers hit the territory of Kherson Oblast 79 times.

item.title: Russians blockade village in Luhansk Oblast, accusing residents of helping Ukraine’s Armed Forces
item.description: Russian invaders are implementing filtration measures in the village of Polovynkine near the city of Starobilsk, Luhansk Oblast, due to the alleged assistance of local residents to the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

item.title: Russians attack coast in vicinity of Ochakiv on Monday
item.description: Russian troops struck the harbour area and the coastal zone of Ochakiv hromada [an administrative unit designating a town, village or several villages and their adjacent territories] several times on Monday, 2 January.

item.title: Ukrainian Armed Forces kill 750 Russians, hit air defence system and helicopter
item.description: The Russian Federation lost about 750 servicemen, and Ukrainian defenders destroyed a Russian helicopter and air defence system, along with five tanks, six artillery systems, a multiple-launch rocket system and seven armoured combat vehicles over the course of 2 January.

item.title: Russia loses another 500 soldiers killed and wounded near Chulanivka
item.description: Ukrainian Defence Forces have launched an attack on the Russians near the village of Chulanivka, Kherson Oblast, with the Russians losing about 500 soldiers killed and wounded. Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine on Facebook, information as of 06:00 on 3 January Quote: "It was confirmed that units from the Defence Forces of Ukraine fired at the enemy's manpower and military equipment near the village of Chulakivka in Kherson Oblast on 31 December.

item.title: Defence forces repel enemy’s attack near 13 settlements and down 27 Shahed UAVs – General Staff report
item.description: On 2 January, Ukrainian Defence Forces repelled attacks from Russian occupiers near 13 settlements and destroyed 27 Iranian-made UAVs. Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine on Facebook, information as of 06:00 on 3 January Quote: "In the course of the past 24 hours, the enemy launched 6 missile and 52 air strikes, and performed 77 attacks using multiple-launch rocket systems.

item.title: Occupiers target reprisals against 30 people suspected of cooperation with Ukrainian Armed Forces in Luhansk Oblast
item.description: The Russian invaders have targeted reprisals against 30 residents of the settlement of Polovynkyne, Luhansk Oblast, who have been accused of working for the Defence Forces of Ukraine. Source: National Resistance Center Quote: "The enemy has blocked the settlement of Polovynkyne in the temporarily occupied territories of Luhansk Oblast for 'filtration measures'.

item.title: Ukrainian Armed Forces reports destruction of Russian ammunition storage point in Svatove
item.description: The Armed Forces of Ukraine has destroyed a Russian ammunition storage point in occupied Svatove, Luhansk Oblast. Source: Strategic Communications Department of the Armed Forces of Ukraine (StratCom) Telegram Details: StratCom reported that the Armed Forces of Ukraine has been recording how the occupiers have been transferring ammunition to the storage point using URAL trucks for almost two weeks now.

item.title: Kramatorsk under Russian attack
item.description: Russian occupiers attacked the city of Kramatorsk in Donetsk Oblast late in the evening on 2 January, and the authorities are urging residents to stay in shelters. Source: City mayor Oleksandr Honcharenko, Ukrainska Pravda sources among military personnel Honcharenko Quote: Kramatorsk is under attack.

item.title: Occupiers prepare for mobilisation in captured territories
item.description: The Russian occupiers are planning to conduct mobilisation among the population of the occupied territories in the south of Ukraine as part of a new wave of mobilisation. Source: National Resistance Center Quote: "Despite statements by high-ranking authorities [of the Russian Federation - ed.

item.title: Sumy Oblast: enemy carries out 70 strikes, damages school
item.description: On 2 January, the Russian occupiers carried out 70 strikes in the Bilopillia hromada [an administrative unit designating a town, village or several villages and their adjacent territories - ed.], Sumy Oblast; a school building was damaged as a result of the shelling.

item.title: Ombudsman will meet "Russian Ombudsman" to discuss release of captured civilians
item.description: Ukrainian Ombudsman Dmytro Lubinets said that he is planning a meeting with the Russian Commissioner Lyudmila Moskalkova regarding the release of prisoners, including civilians. Source: Lubinets on Facebook Quote: "We are not the problem, it is the Russian Federation, because the Russian Federation now wants a separate discussion regarding civilians.

item.title: Russians shell Donetsk Oblast, people wounded
item.description: The Russians launched two missile attacks on Druzhkivka in Donetsk Oblast, and as of now there is information of two people wounded. Source: Deputy Head of the Office of the President Kyrylo Tymoshenko on Telegram Quote: "Druzhkivka, Donetsk Oblast.

item.title: Armed Forces of Ukraine liberate Velykyi Potomkin Island, Kherson Oblast
item.description: As of the evening of 2 January, Ukrainian Armed Forces have liberated the island of Velykyi Potomkin between the left and right banks of the Dnipro River in Kherson Oblast. Source: Informed sources of Ukrainska Pravda, video shared by Oleksii Honcharenko, a parliamentarian of the European Solidarity party on Telegram Details: Honcharenko also shared a video of a Ukrainian soldier talking about the liberation of the island.

item.title: German BILD journalist injured in Ukraine
item.description: BILD journalist Björn Stritzel, who covers the Russian war in Ukraine, received a shrapnel wound while on duty. Source: BILD editor-in-chief Johannes Boyer and injured Stritzel on Twitter Quote: "BILD correspondent Bjorn Stritzel has been injured by shrapnel while covering Russian aggression in Ukraine.

item.title: Explosions rock Sevastopol, Russians say they shoot down drone
item.description: Mikhail Razvozhayev, the so-called "governor" of the temporarily occupied city of Sevastopol, reported that air defence was operating in the city, and a drone was shot down over the sea. Source: Razvozhayev on Telegram, Russian groups on Telegram Quote from Razvozhayev: "The air defence system is operating in Sevastopol.

item.title: Russia plans prolonged attack with Shahed drones – Zelenskyy
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy reported that since the beginning of 2023, the Ukrainian Armed Forces have shot down over 80 Russian drones. According to him, there is information suggesting that Russia is planning a prolonged attack with Shahed drones.

item.title: Ukrainian border guards eliminate over dozen occupiers in two battles in Bakhmut
item.description: On 2 January, Ukrainian border guards took part in two fierce battles in the city of Bakhmut and near the village of Pidhorodne [Donetsk Oblast - ed.], as a result of which they repelled the attack of the Russian invaders and destroyed more than a dozen soldiers.

item.title: Russians hold 474 residents of Kherson Oblast captive
item.description: As of 2 January, 474 residents of Kherson Oblast, who were abdicated by Russian militants, remain in captivity. Source: Suspilne with reference to the press secretary of Kherson Oblast Prosecutor's Office, Anastasiia Vesilovska Quote from Vesilovska: "As of this moment, the investigators know of 683 liberated Ukrainian citizens; 474 persons remain in illegal captivity.

item.title: Russians cause over US$35 billion worth of damage to Ukraine’s ecology
item.description: Ukrainian Minister of Defence Oleksii Reznikov reported that the Russian occupiers caused damage to the Ukrainian ecology in the amount of US$35.3 billion. Source: Reznikov on Twitter Quote: "The damage to the ecology caused by Russia is estimated at $35.

item.title: Ukraine-EU summit to be held in Kyiv
Ukraine's South and East believed in NATO: what do regions think of Ukraine's future
General Staff confirms attack on occupiers in Makiivka, losses still being determined
item.description: The General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine reported that on 31 December, Ukrainian defenders destroyed 10 units of military equipment in the area of concentration of military personnel in the city of Makiivka [Donetsk Oblast]; the losses of Russian military personnel are still being determined.

item.title: Despite losses, occupiers continue their offensive on Bakhmut front
item.description: As of the evening of 2 January, the occupiers continued to focus on conducting offensive operations on the Bakhmut front. Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine Quote: "The enemy launched a missile attack and 28 air strikes.

item.title: Mobilised soldiers from Samara Oblast are among those killed in Makiivka
item.description: Among the Russian soldiers destroyed in the temporarily occupied Makiivka were those mobilised from the Samara Oblast of the Russian Federation. Source: Meduza [an independent Russian media outlet - ed.

item.title: Ukraine's Commander-in-Chief sums up results of 2022: 40% of territories liberated since February
item.description: Valerii Zaluzhnyi, Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, said that during 2022, the Armed Forces of Ukraine destroyed more than 100,000 Russian invaders, freed 40% of the territories occupied during the full-scale invasion, and destroyed almost 42,000 Russian explosive devices.

item.title: Russian propagandist Solovyov urges Russians not to fear death: Life is overrated
item.description: Russian propagandist Vladimir Solovyov has called on Russians not to be afraid of death, saying that "life is greatly overrated", but death is inevitable anyway. Source: Solovyov on the air of his program on Rossiya 1 [Russian state-owned television channel - ed.

item.title: Security Service of Ukraine reports suspicion to Head of Russian Central Bank who may end up on international wanted list
item.description: The Security Service of Ukraine has notified Elvira Nabiullina, the head of the Central Bank of the Russian Federation, of suspicion due to her participation in financing the military groups of the aggressor country.

item.title: Russian Ministry of Defence confirms elimination of occupiers in Makiivka, Donetsk Oblast, but lowers number of casualties
item.description: The Ministry of Defense of the Russian Federation has confirmed that the Armed Forces of Ukraine destroyed a group of Russian militants in the temporarily occupied city of Makiivka, Donetsk Oblast, but says that the losses are much smaller than those announced by StratCom [Ukrainian non-governmental organisation - ed.

item.title: Sevastopol's Russian-appointed puppet governor moves family and property to Cyprus
item.description: Mikhail Razvozhayev, the so-called "governor" of Sevastopol, has moved all his property, including his dogs and cats, to Cyprus. Source: Special Operations Forces of the National Resistance Center Details: The puppet governor has also taken his children abroad.

item.title: If Putin saves face, it will be the last nail in the coffin of postwar order – Polish Ambassador to UN
item.description: Krzysztof Szczerski, Poland's Ambassador to the United Nations, believes that Western attempts to allow the Russian President to save face will completely kill off the international order that was established after World War II.

item.title: Ursula von der Leyen holds first conversation of the new year with Zelenskyy
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, has held her first phone conversation of the new year with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, saying that she is looking forward to visiting Ukraine again soon.

item.title: Occupiers in Berdiansk claim they shot down homemade UAV
item.description: Occupation authorities have claimed that Russian air defence destroyed a UAV in the occupied city of Berdiansk (Zaporizhzhia Oblast, Ukraine). Source: Volodymyr Rohov, the Kremlin-appointed puppet leader of Zaporizhzia Oblast Quote: "Here is official information about an explosion in Berdiansk.

item.title: Military exercise of Russian and Belarusian troops prolonged once again
item.description: Russia and Belarus have extended training of the regional joint force of the so-called Union State [Russia and Belarus] until at least 8 January. Source: Telegram channel of Belaruski Hajun, an independent Belarusian military monitoring media outlet Details: The outlet referred to a schedule of exercises on training grounds in Belarus.

item.title: EU Ambassador does not see threat of reduction in support for Ukraine
item.description: Matti Maasikas, the EU Ambassador to Ukraine, does not see a threat of a reduction in support for Ukraine from EU countries. Source: Maasikas in an interview with Ukrinform news agency, cited by European Pravda Details: Maasikas has pointed out that the European Union had to become a real geopolitical figure and take a firm stance in order to correspond with its own declared values after Russia's open invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Russia states Ukrainian UAV shot down near Voronezh city
item.description: The Russian Federation has claimed that a drone launched from Ukraine was shot down near the city of Voronezh on 2 January. Source: Kremlin-aligned news outlet TASS and Russian governors Details: As the press service of the authorities of Voronezh Oblast has reported, the air defence forces shot down a UAV launched from Ukraine near Voronezh.

item.title: Situation in energy system under control despite Russian attack at night
item.description: The situation in Ukraine's energy system is completely under control despite the damage caused by the Russian attack on energy infrastructure on the night of 1-2 January. Source: Press service for Ukrenergo, a state power-generating company Details: There was damage caused by the attack, Ukrenergo reported.

item.title: Christmas tree in dugout and tears from President's speech: how soldiers celebrated New Year on front
item.description: Ukrainians greeted the New Year 2023 amid the war, listening to the sounds of attacks and air defence working. Ukrainian soldiers continued defending our state on New Year's Eve. Journalists from the Ukrainskyi Svidok (Ukrainian Witness) news outlet went to the 5th Separate Assault Regiment, who are currently at the front, in order to celebrate New Year's Eve with them.

item.title: Energy facility and 11 private houses damaged in Kyiv Oblast
item.description: 11 damaged private houses, as well as a critical infrastructure facility, were reported in the Fastiv and Obukhiv districts of Kyiv Oblast on the morning of 2 January, after a Russian drone attack. Source: Oleksii Kuleba, Head of Kyiv Oblast Military Administration Details: Kyiv Oblast repelled drone attacks for the second night in a row.

item.title: Constant Russian attacks and energy terror did not demoralise Ukrainians: majority is opposed to concessions
item.description: Opinion polls have confirmed the firm unreadiness of Ukrainians to agree on territorial concessions despite the pressure and terror carried out by the aggressor state, Russia. Source: results of the survey conducted by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology (KIIS) on 4-27 December 2022 Quote: "In May, July and September 2022, we asked a question about the readiness for territorial concessions to achieve peace as soon as possible.

item.title: Kherson Oblast: Russians attack market in Beryslav this morning, 5 people injured
item.description: Russian invaders attacked a market in Beryslav, Kherson Oblast, on the morning of 2 January. Five people have been injured as a result of the attack. Source: Yaroslav Yanushevych, Head of Kherson Oblast Military Administration Quote from Yanushevych: "The Army of the Russian Federation has carried out another terrorist attack on Kherson Oblast.

item.title: Missile attack on Kyiv on 31 December: one injured person died in intensive care unit
item.description: One of the people injured in a Russian missile attack on Kyiv on 31 December died. Source: Vitalii Klitschko, Mayor of Kyiv, on Telegram Quote: "One of the people injured in a Russian missile attack on the capital on 31 December died this morning.

item.title: Russians continue to attack border areas of Kharkiv and Sumy oblasts
item.description: Russian soldiers have attacked several settlements in Kharkiv Oblast and two hromadas in Sumy Oblast [a hromada is an administrative unit designating a town, village or several villages and their adjacent territories - ed.

item.title: Russia loses about 720 soldiers over first day of the year - General Staff
item.description: Ukrainian defenders have killed approximately 720 Russian invaders and destroyed 44 UAVs over the past 24 hours. The Russian Federation has also lost another six artillery systems and nine armoured combat vehicles.

item.title: 39-40 attack drones and Kh-59 missile shot down over Ukraine overnight
item.description: The Ukrainian Defence Forces destroyed all 39 attack drones that were launched to attack Ukraine by Russian forces, along with 2 Orlan-10 reconnaissance UAVs and one Kh-59 air-launched guided missile, on the night of 1-2 January 2023.

item.title: Seven Shahed drones shot down over Mykolaiv Oblast
item.description: Seven Russian Shahed-136 kamikaze drones have been shot down in Mykolaiv Oblast over the past 24 hours. Source: Vitalii Kim, Head of Mykolaiv Oblast Military Administration, according to the information from district military administrations and Air Command Pivden (South) as of 08:00 on 2 January 2023 Quote: "Military means and personnel from air defence units in Mykolaiv Oblast have destroyed six enemy Shahed-136 drones, and another one was destroyed by soldiers from the National Guard of Ukraine.

item.title: Ukrainian Armed Forces repel Russian attacks near 11 settlements – General Staff report
item.description: The Armed Forces of Ukraine repelled Russian attacks near 11 settlements on 1 January. Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine on Facebook, information as of 06:00 on 2 January Quote: "During the past day, the enemy carried out 51 airstrikes and deployed 44 Shahed-136 drones.

item.title: Energy facilities damaged in night attack on Kyiv, power cuts initiated
item.description: Energy infrastructure has been damaged as a result of an overnight Russian attack on Kyiv, causing emergency power cuts in the capital. Source: Vitalii Klitschko, Mayor of Kyiv, on Telegram Quote: "Energy infrastructure facilities were damaged in the overnight attack on the capital.

item.title: Russia states Ukrainian UAV attacked energy facility in Bryansk Oblast
item.description: Alexander Bogomaz, Governor of Bryansk Oblast in the Russian Federation, has stated that a Ukrainian UAV damaged an energy facility in the Klimovsky district of the oblast. Source: Bogomaz on Telegram Quore: "A Ukrainian UAV attacked the Klimovsky district this morning [2 January - ed.

item.title: Ukraine’s Armed Forces kill 400 occupiers in Makiivka on New Year’s Eve
item.description: The Defence Forces of Ukraine launched an attack on a Russian military base in occupied Makiivka in Donetsk Oblast on New Year's Eve, killing 400 and wounding 300 occupiers. Source: Department of Strategic Communications of the Armed Forces of Ukraine (StratCom) on Telegram Details: StratCom reported that, thanks to a precise strike in Makiivka, about 400 mobilised Russians were killed and about 300 more invaders were wounded with varying degrees of severity.

item.title: Air defence shoots down 20 air targets over Kyiv
item.description: Air defence forces have shot down 16 air targets over Kyiv. Source: Kyiv City Military Administration on Telegram Quote: "As of this minute [02:37 - ed.], 16 air targets have been shot down over the capital.

item.title: Air defence activated in Kyiv and Kyiv Oblast, explosions rock capital
item.description: Air defence forces are operating in Kyiv and Kyiv Oblast, repelling an attack from Russian drones. Sources: Oleksii Kuleba, Head of Kyiv Oblast Military Administration, on Telegram; Ukrainska Pravda; Kyiv City Military Administration on Telegram Quote from Kuleba: "Kyiv Oblast: air defence is in operation.

item.title: Air defence forces shoot down 9 drones and 1 missile over Dnipropetrovsk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts
item.description: Air defence forces have destroyed nine Iranian-made Shahed UAVs and one high-precision guided missile over Dnipropetrovsk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts. Source: Air Command Skhid (East) on Facebook Quote: "The air and anti-aircraft missile forces have destroyed six Shahed attack UAVs and one Kh-59MK2 high-precision guided missile that was going towards the city of Dnipro over Dnipropetrovsk and Zaporizhzhia oblasts.

item.title: Air attack on Kyiv: building damaged, 19-year-old young man injured
item.description: A 19-year-old young man has sustained injuries and been hospitalised as a result of a Russian UAV attack on Kyiv. Fragments of a shot-down drone damaged a house in Desnianskyi district of the capital. Source: Vitalii Klitschko, Mayor of Kyiv, on Telegram; Kyrylo Tymoshenko, Deputy Head of the Office of the President, on Telegram; Kyiv City Military Administration on Telegram Quote from Klitschko: "An injured 19-year-old young man has been taken to hospital in the Desnianskyi district of the capital.

item.title: Explosions in Dnipro, air defence operating in Poltava Oblast
item.description: Explosions have rang out in the city of Dnipro, and air defence has been deployed in Poltava Oblast. Sources: Dmytro Lunin, Hear of Poltava Oblast Military Administration on Telegram; Suspilne, Ukrainian public broadcaster, on Telegram; Mykola Lukashuk, Head of Dnipropetrovsk Oblast Council, on Telegram Details: The air assault on Ukraine continues.

item.title: Fragments of Russian Kh-55 missile found in Kyiv Oblast
item.description: Fragments of a Russian Kh-55 missile, shot down in an attack on 31 December, were found in one of the districts of Kyiv Oblast on Sunday, 1 January 2023. Source: Andrii Niebytov, Head of the National Police in Kyiv Oblast, on Telegram Quote: "Fragments of a Russian missile were discovered in one of the districts of Kyiv Oblast after yesterday's large-scale missile attack by the enemy.

item.title: Sumy Oblast sustains 114 strikes in one day, with architectural monument damaged
item.description: On Sunday, 1 January, the Russians performed 114 strikes on 5 hromadas[an administrative unit designating a town, village or several villages and their adjacent territories - ed.] in Sumy Oblast, damaging an architectural monument, a community arts centre and a village council building.

item.title: Secretary of Ukraine’s Security Council: Russia could become colony of neighbouring countries, it is very dangerous
item.description: Oleksii Danilov, Secretary of the National Security and Defence Council, has warned that Russia could become a "colony" of one of its neighbouring countries, a situation that could be very dangerous. Sources: Danilov on air during the 24/7 national joint newscast Quote: "If anyone thinks that 2023 is going to be easy, that the Russians have run out of everything, and everything will be fine - I do not share this point of view.

item.title: Zelenskyy: Fear reigns in Russia, and rightly so
item.description: Volodymyr Zelenskyy, the President of Ukraine, has remarked that the unity of Ukrainians contrasts significantly with the fear that reigns in Russia. Source: evening address of the President Quote: "The Russian terrorists are as pathetic in the new year as they were before.

item.title: Zelenskyy expects "practical steps" towards convergence with EU within next six months
item.description: Ukraine expects that it will be possible for practical steps towards European integration to be taken during Sweden's presidency of the Council of the European Union. Source: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, while congratulating Sweden on assuming the presidency of the Council of the European Union, cited by European Pravda "Congratulations to the Prime Minister of Sweden [Magdalena Andersson - ed.

item.title: Shevchenko University buildings significantly damaged in Kyiv attack
item.description: Buildings on the Exhibition campus of the Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv have suffered significant damage as a result of the Russian missile attack on 31 December. Source: Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv on Facebook Aftermath of the attack on 31 December.

item.title: Russians shell occupied Kherson Oblast to force "evacuation"
item.description: Russian troops are shelling the occupied settlements of Kherson Oblast in order to destabilise the humanitarian situation and force the local population into the so-called "voluntary evacuation". Source: General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine Quote: "In order to destabilise the humanitarian situation in the temporarily occupied territories of Kherson Oblast and to force the local population into the so-called 'voluntary evacuation', the Russian occupying forces are shelling Oleshky, Hola Prystan, Plavni as well as villages with dachas [dacha is a sort of a summer house, usually with a little plot of land where people grow vegetables, fruit trees and berries, or keep a garden - ed.

item.title: Electricity cut off in city of Sloviansk after Russian shelling.
item.description:
Mayor of Sloviansk Vadim Lyakh reported that Russian shelling damaged a high-voltage line, but there are no casualties.
The post Electricity cut off in city of Sloviansk after Russian shelling. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Zelensky: More than 200,000 Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia.
item.description:
In his daily address on June 1, President Volodymyr Zelensky said that Russia continues to forcibly move both adults and children into mostly remote areas of Russia, underscoring that this is one of Moscow’s “most heinous war crimes.” He added that the children deported include orphans and children with parents.
The post Zelensky: More than 200,000 Ukrainian children have been deported to Russia. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Did the War End? Ep. 1: Introduction
item.description:
“Did the War End?” is the Kyiv Independent’s podcast that brings together three young Ukrainians exploring what it means to be a nation at war, speaking with experts and everyday Ukrainians to help them answer pressing questions. (Illustration: Karolina Gulshani)
The early hours of Feb. 24, 2022 were not something any Ukrainian could have imagined. It was a very regular night. Then, millions of people across the country woke up to the sounds of explosions, as Russia began its full-scale attack on Ukraine, including its capital, Kyiv.
In this episode of our podcast “Did the War End?” the hosts Anastasiia Lapatina, Catarina Buchatskiy, and Agatha Gorski discuss how they learned that their country was under attack, how they reacted, and what it feels like to look back at the start of Russia’s war three months into it. They also interview Olga Rudenko, the chief editor of the Kyiv Independent, and Anna Myroniuk, the Kyiv Independent’s head of investigations, about the decisions they had to make that night.
The post Did the War End? Ep. 1: Introduction appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Lviv Oblast Governor: Russian cruise missiles ‘severely damaged’ railway infrastructure.
item.description:
Governor Maksym Kozytskyi reported that Russia launched a missile overnight from the Black Sea and hit Lviv Oblast. Kozytskyi added that five people were injured, four of whom have been hospitalized.
The post Lviv Oblast Governor: Russian cruise missiles ‘severely damaged’ railway infrastructure. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Slovakia to send eight Zuzana 2 howitzers to Ukraine.
item.description:
The Slovak Defense Ministry said that the self-propelled Zuzana 2 howitzers will be delivered under a commercial contract that a state-controlled producer had signed.
The post Slovakia to send eight Zuzana 2 howitzers to Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: General Staff: Russia has lost 30,850 troops in Ukraine since Feb. 24.
item.description:
Ukraine’s General Staff reported on June 2 that Russia had also lost 1,363 tanks, 3,354 armored vehicles, 2,325 vehicles and fuel tanks, 661 artillery pieces, 207 multiple launch rocket systems, 95 air defense systems, 175 helicopters, 210 airplanes, 521 drones, and 13 boats.
The post General Staff: Russia has lost 30,850 troops in Ukraine since Feb. 24. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russia shells Kharkiv overnight, killing one, injuring another.
item.description:
Kharkiv Oblast Governor Oleh Synehubov said the Russians shelled two city districts during the night.
The post Russia shells Kharkiv overnight, killing one, injuring another. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: General Staff: Russia faces shortage of drones.
item.description:
Ukraine’s military reported that the Russians are losing drones, and they have already begun using the ones owned by the Ministry of Emergency Situations.
The post General Staff: Russia faces shortage of drones. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: UK Defense Ministry: Russia continues to make ‘steady local gains,’ takes control of most of Sievierodonetsk.
item.description:
The U.K. defense ministry said in its daily briefing that Ukraine likely still has control over the main road into the Sievierodonetsk pocket but Russia continues to advance despite heavy losses, enabling a heavy concentration of artillery. It is likely that Russia will need a short tactical pause before attempting to cross the Siversky Donets River, a natural barrier that is vital for the Russians to cross as they secure Luhansk Oblast.
The post UK Defense Ministry: Russia continues to make ‘steady local gains,’ takes control of most of Sievierodonetsk. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Institute for the Study of War: Russian forces try to advance on Lysychansk to avoid crossing Siversky Donets River.
item.description:
According to the U.S. think tank, Russian forces have made “incremental advances” north of Sloviansk and Avdiivka, Donetsk Oblast, with “limited success.”
The post Institute for the Study of War: Russian forces try to advance on Lysychansk to avoid crossing Siversky Donets River. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Sky News: General confirms US conducts offensive hacking operation in support of Ukraine.
item.description:
In an interview, NSA Director Paul Nakasone said the U.S. has “conducted a series of operations across the full spectrum; offensive, defensive, [and] information operations” in response to Russia’s full-scale invasion. Nakasone said their activities are lawful and conducted with complete civilian oversight of the military.
The post Sky News: General confirms US conducts offensive hacking operation in support of Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Stoltenberg: Russia unlikely to retaliate after US provision of advanced weapons to Ukraine.
item.description:
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told CNN on June 1 that he does not “foresee that because what NATO allies and NATO is doing is to provide support to Ukraine to uphold the right for self-defense, and this is a right which is enshrined in the UN treaty.”
The post Stoltenberg: Russia unlikely to retaliate after US provision of advanced weapons to Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: CNN: UK to send Ukraine long-range rocket systems.
item.description:
The U.K. will send multiple-launch rocket systems, or M270 launchers, to Ukraine, U.K. Defense Secretary Ben Wallace said on June 1. M270 launchers can hit targets up to 80 kilometers away, giving “a significant boost in capability for the Ukrainian forces,” according to a statement from the U.K. Foreign Office. The decision is “closely coordinated” with the U.S.’ provision of HIMARS to Ukraine, a variant of the M270 launchers. The U.K. will also train Ukrainian troops to use the rocket systems.
The post CNN: UK to send Ukraine long-range rocket systems. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Reuters: Civilians take shelter in chemical plant as Russia shells Sievierodonetsk.
item.description:
Luhansk Oblast Governor Serhiy Haidai said authorities fear the Azot chemical plant may still contain dangerous materials. However, he said the situation will not become the “second Azovstal.”
The post Reuters: Civilians take shelter in chemical plant as Russia shells Sievierodonetsk. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Reuters: US intends to sell Ukraine armed drones in coming days.
item.description:
The U.S. plans to sell Ukraine four long-endurance MQ-1C Gray Eagle drones, which can be armed with up to eight Hellfire missiles, undisclosed sources told Reuters. While the sale could still be blocked by Congress, it is significant because it would provide Ukraine with an advanced reusable U.S. system able to hit deep inside Russia.
The post Reuters: US intends to sell Ukraine armed drones in coming days. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Poland to sell Ukraine additional 60 KRAB self-propelled howitzers.
item.description:
Polish media outlet Dziennik reported that these weapons will be delivered in the next few months. In May, Poland sent 18 KRAB self-propelled howitzers to Ukraine.
The post Poland to sell Ukraine additional 60 KRAB self-propelled howitzers. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Lviv Oblast Governor: Russian missile strike injures 5 people.
item.description:
Maksym Kozytsky said that those injured by the cruise missile strike on Lviv Oblast’s Stryisky District on June 1 are not in critical condition. Kozytsky said more information will be provided in the morning, local time.
The post Lviv Oblast Governor: Russian missile strike injures 5 people. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Washington Post: US defends decision to provide Ukraine with HIMARS.
item.description:
U.S. Under Secretary of Defense for Policy Colin Kahl dismissed criticism that the delayed provision of M142 High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems to Ukraine comes too late, saying they will “arrive in a time frame that’s relevant.” The satellite-guided weapons are the most advanced arms sent to Ukraine by the U.S. thus far and will reportedly arrive soon. U.S. State Secretary Antony Blinken also dismissed Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov’s comment that providing HIMARS is “pouring fuel on the fire,” saying “the best way to avoid escalation is for Russia to stop the aggression and war that it started.”
The post Washington Post: US defends decision to provide Ukraine with HIMARS. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Ukrainian troops repel 13 Russian attacks, destroy military equipment.
item.description:
Operational Command “East” reports that Ukraine’s forces have repelled 13 Russian attacks in the east of the country. Russia has reportedly lost 20 units of military equipment, including two tanks, six artillery pieces, eight armored combat vehicles and four other vehicles. Additionally, Ukraine’s Air Force downed seven Russian “Orlan-10” UAVs.
The post Ukrainian troops repel 13 Russian attacks, destroy military equipment. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: EU imposes partial oil embargo but keeps funding Putin’s war through gas payments
item.description:
*The sections of the second Nord Stream 2 pipeline laid from the German shore and Danish waters, connected in a so-called above water tie-in, on Sept. 10, 2021. (Nord Stream 2 / Axel Schmidt)*
The European Union on May 31 finally agreed on a partial embargo on Russian oil after months of delays and disagreements.
However, the move was criticized by some Ukrainians and supporters of Ukraine as “too little and too late.”
“If you ask me, I would say far too slow, far too late and definitely not enough,” Ihor Zhovkva, a deputy chief of staff for President Volodymyr Zelensky, told Reuters.
Paradoxically, the very countries that support Ukraine have enabled Russian dictator Vladimir Putin to get billions of dollars in oil and gas revenue, financing his aggression against Ukraine.
Since Putin launched his full-scale invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, there have been more and more calls in the European Union for an oil and gas embargo against Russia. The main goal of the embargo is to deprive Putin of the opportunity to fund the war.
The oil embargo will be less painful for the European economy, since it would be relatively easy to replace Russian oil.
A gas embargo is more tricky since it will take more time and effort to entirely get rid of Russian gas.
But analysts say that both of them are feasible, and the main issue at stake is political will.
European governments will have to withstand pressure from vested interests, the business lobby and Russian agents of influence.
While there has been progress on the oil embargo, a gas embargo is still opposed by the EU establishment.
“Russia wants to see at such (EU) meetings not a unified EU but 27 individual states – fragments that can’t be put together,” Zelensky said on May 30. “Today we see simultaneously the Russian offensive in the Donbas destroying our cities and Europe’s unity running the risk of being shattered.”
*Statistics *
On May 31, the EU agreed to impose an embargo on seaborne Russian crude oil within six months and seaborne Russian oil products within eight months.
Pipeline oil will be “temporarily” exempt from the embargo during an indefinite period, with Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic being able to import Russian oil via the Druzhba pipeline beyond the end of 2022.
Seaborne deliveries of Russian oil, which are subject to the embargo, account for more than 60% of the EU’s imports of Russian oil. Additionally, Poland and Germany have pledged to stop their imports of Russian oil by pipeline, which is expected to cut the EU’s total imports of Russian oil to 90% by the end of 2022.
Europe’s dependence on Russian energy is significant – a result of what critics see as the EU’s failure and reluctance to diversify its energy sources for many years.
Russian gas accounts for about 40% of the EU’s consumption, and Russian oil and oil products account for around 30%.
The EU has paid dozens of billions of euros for Russian oil and gas since the invasion began, allowing the Russian economy to withstand the sanctions and enabling Putin to continue his costly invasion of Ukraine.
Russia’s dependence on the European oil and gas market is also immense, which will potentially lead to devastating effects for the aggressor country when the embargo is enforced.
Russia exports 70% of its gas and 60% of its oil and oil products to Europe. Moreover, oil and gas account for half of the Russian budget and half of its exports.
*Redirecting oil supplies *
There is the opinion that the oil embargo will be useless because Russia will be able to divert exports to other countries – such as India and China. One of its proponents is German economist Jorg Schindler.
Oleksandr Kharchenko, managing director of the Energy Industry Research Center, a Kyiv-based think tank, disagrees with this theory. He told the Kyiv Independent that there are no oil pipelines to ship this oil somewhere else and no possibility to transport most of this oil by tanker. There is also fierce competition on the oil market, and Russia would not be able to elbow its way there, he added.
Kharchenko said that Russia would only be able to sell a minor part of the oil with huge discounts.
Mikhail Krutikhin, a partner at Russian consulting company RusEnergy, and Oleg Buklemishev, head of Russia’s Association of Independent Economic Analysis Centers, agreed that Russia is unlikely to redirect most of its oil supplies to China, India and other markets, as cited by Deutsche Welle.
They said that Russia does not have necessary oil pipelines and logistics and would have to compete with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates for new markets.
*Opposition to the embargo*
The usual argument against the embargo is that the European economy will incur significant costs, and energy prices will skyrocket even more.
But Ukraine’s supporters argue that extraordinary times require extraordinary decisions, and Europe has to endure some hardship if it wants to stop Russia’s aggression. Moreover, analysts say that eventually the market is likely to adapt, and the hardships will not be as drastic if the embargo is gradual.
Hungary has been the most vehement opponent of the oil embargo. The country is headed by Victor Orban, a long-time friend of Putin.
Other countries that have been lukewarm about the embargo inlcude Germany, Slovakia, Austria, and the Czech Republic.
However, countries like Slovakia depend a lot on Russian oil but they do not have relations with Putin similar to Hungary, according to Ukrainian political analyst Volodymyr Fesenko.
Germany was initially against an embargo on Russian oil but then changed its stance.
Fesenko argued that delays with the embargo had been due both to the business lobby and Russian political influence.
“Economic interests dominate, and politics is an additional factor,” he told the Kyiv Independent. “Putin has corrupted part of European elites and mass media.”
There is a strong Russian lobby in Greece, Germany, Austria, France, and Italy, Fesenko added. Moreover, France and Germany are currently trying to negotiate with Putin, which may also explain their delays with the embargo, he said.
“They support Ukraine morally but when it comes to decisions, they start to vacillate and maneuver,” he added.
*Gas embargo *
The situation with the gas embargo is more difficult than with oil. While oil can be transported both by tanker and pipeline, gas is mostly transported via pipelines. The alternative option – shipping liquified natural gas by sea – is less widespread and less developed.
Economists agree that it will be impossible to replace all of the Russian gas quickly. Kharchenko said that it is unlikely to happen within several weeks or months.
The EU still mostly opposes a gas embargo. Austrian Chancellor Karl Nehammer said on May 31 that a gas embargo would not be included in the EU’s next package of sanctions against Russia.
However, analysts say that a gradual reduction in Russian gas supplies to zero is feasible. Kharchenko said that it’s possible to get rid of Russian gas in one and a half years.
There are analysts who are trying to prove that it’s impossible but they are mostly ones backed by Russian gas giant Gazprom, he added.
The EU has considered compensating for the lost Russian supplies by increasing liquified natural gas (LNG) imports, boosting energy efficiency and developing nuclear power and other alternative sources of energy.
Europe can gradually create infrastructure, including pipelines, for transporting gas from Russia’s competitors, Kharchenko said.
Some countries have already started to move in this direction.
During the invasion, Germany has cut the share of Russian gas in its consumption from 35% to 12%.
*Russian blackmail *
As Europe considered the oil and gas embargo, Putin resorted to blackmail.
In March Putin demanded that European consumers pay for gas in rubles in an effort to strengthen the Russian currency amid its depreciation due to the sanctions. This was a violation of the gas supply contracts, which stipulated payment in dollars and euros, as well as of the European sanctions against Russia.
Eventually the European Union refused to pay in rubles. As a result, the Kremlin has come up with a scheme under which buyers are obliged to deposit euros or dollars into an account at Russia’s Gazprombank, which has to convert them into rubles and transfer the payment to Russian gas giant Gazprom.
But Tim McPhee, a spokesman for the European Commission, said on May 12 that the scheme would breach EU sanctions because it involves Russia’s central bank, which has been sanctioned by the European Union.
Some companies have opened accounts with Gazprombank under this scheme but its legality is still being considered by the European Commission.
Kharchenko argued that the new scheme is just a face-saving gesture for Putin. It does not actually help the Russian economy or strengthen the ruble, he added.
In April Russia resorted to blackmail again, halting gas supplies to Poland and Bulgaria due to their refusal to pay for the gas in rubles. Russia also stopped gas exports to Finland on May 21 and to the Netherlands on May 31.
The move was seen as payback for the countries’ support for Ukraine, as well as for Finland’s intention to join NATO.
“The worse the blackmail by Russia, the faster they will reject Russian gas,” Kharchenko said.
The post EU imposes partial oil embargo but keeps funding Putin’s war through gas payments appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Kyiv City Prosecutor’s Office investigates Kryukiv Railway Car Building Works over alleged embezzlement to a Russian entity.
item.description:
The investigation alleges the plant purchased parts for car construction from Russian companies at inflated prices when it could have bought the same parts at a lower price from Ukraine.
The post Kyiv City Prosecutor’s Office investigates Kryukiv Railway Car Building Works over alleged embezzlement to a Russian entity. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Gazprom leaves London Stock Exchange.
item.description:
Gazprom left the London Stock Exchange following the Russian government’s demand that Russian companies quit Western stock markets.
The post Gazprom leaves London Stock Exchange. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russians hit Sloviansk with Iskander missiles, killing 3 people and wounding 6.
item.description:
The missile attack occurred on May 31, and damaged a school and at least seven residential buildings, according to Pavlo Kyrylenko, the governor of Donetsk Oblast.
The post Russians hit Sloviansk with Iskander missiles, killing 3 people and wounding 6. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Verkhovna Rada dismisses ombudsman Denisova.
item.description:
234 lawmakers voted to dismiss Lyudmyla Denisova. Earlier, Ukrainian journalists and activists have expressed concerns over Denisova’s reports of rapes by Russian soldiers, that were sometimes seen as insensitive or disrespectful towards survivors.
The post Verkhovna Rada dismisses ombudsman Denisova. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Austrian chancellor: Next package of Russia sanctions won’t include gas embargo.
item.description:
Karl Nehammer claimed that it would be much more difficult to replace Russian gas than Russian oil. Earlier the European Union had agreed to impose an embargo on Russian oil with a “temporary exemption” for pipeline oil. European countries have faced criticism for effectively financing Russian aggression against Ukraine by paying billions of dollars for Russian oil and gas.
The post Austrian chancellor: Next package of Russia sanctions won’t include gas embargo. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: General Staff: One more Russian offensive towards Sloviansk fails.
item.description:
Ukraine’s General Staff said that Russian troops had unsuccessfully tried to storm the village of Dovhenke near Sloviansk, Donetsk Oblast. Russian troops are also trying to storm Zolote, Komyshuvakha, Nyrkove, Berestove, Pokrovske and Dolomitne near Bakhmut in Donetsk Oblast, the General Staff said.
The post General Staff: One more Russian offensive towards Sloviansk fails. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Ukrainian court jails 2 Russian soldiers charged with war crimes.
item.description:
The court sentenced the two Russians, Alexander Bobykin and Alexander Ivanov, to 11.5 years in prison for shelling residential areas in Kharkiv Oblast.
The post Ukrainian court jails 2 Russian soldiers charged with war crimes. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: German defense committee chief urges Scholz to unblock supplies of armored vehicles to Ukraine.
item.description:
Marie-Agnes Strack-Zimmermann, head of the German parliament’s defense committee, has called on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s office to deliver 50 Marder infantry fighting vehicles to Ukraine as soon as possible. German media reported earlier that Scholz had blocked Marder supplies for weeks.
The post German defense committee chief urges Scholz to unblock supplies of armored vehicles to Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: UK Defense Ministry: Russia achieves local successes by massing forces.
item.description:
The ministry said that the strategy of massing forces and fires in a relatively small area had enabled Russian troops to achieve local successes. In contrast, during the first month of the large-scale invasion, Russia suffered military setbacks after scattering its forces over a huge area. The ministry said that Russia’s capture of Lyman in Donetsk Oblast will help it to achieve its main operational goal, which remains the encirclement of Sievierodonetsk and the closure of the pocket around Ukrainian forces in Luhansk Oblast. Russia’s political goal is likely to occupy the full territory of the Donbas, the ministry added.
The post UK Defense Ministry: Russia achieves local successes by massing forces. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Prosecutor General’s Office: Russia’s war has killed 240 children, injured 436.
item.description:
The figures are expected to be higher since they do not include child casualties in the areas where hostilities are ongoing and in the occupied areas, the Prosecutor General’s Office said.
The post Prosecutor General’s Office: Russia’s war has killed 240 children, injured 436. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: US rejects Russia’s offer to unblock Ukrainian ports in exchange for lifting sanctions.
item.description:
U.S. Department of State spokesman Ned Price called Russia’s suggestion to unblock Ukrainian ports in exchange for lifting sanctions “empty promises.” “The quickest solution to rising raw material prices and rising food prices around the world is to end the Russians’ brutal war,” Price said.
The post US rejects Russia’s offer to unblock Ukrainian ports in exchange for lifting sanctions. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: World Bank President: Russia’s war in Ukraine could trigger global recession.
item.description:
David Malpass said on May 25 that Europe, China, and the U.S. were seeing slower growth. Meanwhile, shortfalls in fertilizer, food stocks, and energy supplies hit developing countries.
The post World Bank President: Russia’s war in Ukraine could trigger global recession. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: UK Intelligence: Russia’s airborne forces ‘heavily involved in several notable tactical failures in Ukraine’
item.description:
These failures include the attempted advance on Kyiv via Hostomel Airfield in March, the stalled progress on the Izium axis since April, and the recent failed and costly crossings of the Siverskyi Donets River, according to the latest intelligence update by the U.K. Defense Ministry. The misemployment of its elite airborne forces “highlights how Putin’s significant investment in the armed forces over the last 15 years has resulted in an unbalanced overall force,” the Ministry wrote.
The post UK Intelligence: Russia’s airborne forces ‘heavily involved in several notable tactical failures in Ukraine’ appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: ISW: Russia preparing for Battle of Sievierodonetsk.
item.description:
The Institute for the Study of War said in its May 25 assessment that the intensity of Russian artillery and air attack, combined with the massing of Russian forces from elsewhere suggests Russia may start its offensive on Sievierodonetsk prior to cutting off Ukrainian ground lines of communication. Russia “may need to conduct a ground offensive on Sievierodonetsk in the upcoming days to maintain their pace after committing a significant portion of personnel, artillery, aviation, and logistics to the front,” the ISW wrote.
The post ISW: Russia preparing for Battle of Sievierodonetsk. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Media: NATO members informally agree not to supply Ukraine with aircraft and tanks
item.description:
Citing its sources in NATO, the German Press Agency reported that alliance members have informally agreed not to supply the weapons to Ukraine, fearing Russia could see the delivery of Western tanks and combat aircraft as entering the war and take retaliatory measures, German newspaper Die Zeit reported.
The post Media: NATO members informally agree not to supply Ukraine with aircraft and tanks appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Nike will not renew franchise agreement with Russian retailer
item.description:
The company said in a statement that “due to operational challenges in Russia, Nike has made the decision not to renew or enter into any new business commitments,” Russian business daily Vedomosti reported. Earlier in March, Nike said it would temporarily close its Nike-owned and operated stores in Russia but some locations managed by its Russian retailer, Up & Run, remained open.
The post Nike will not renew franchise agreement with Russian retailer appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Zelensky: ‘The world wasn’t ready for Ukrainian bravery’
item.description:
“For the bravery of all our people who are not inferior to Russia and continue to defend our state,” President Zelensky said during his nightly address. In reference to doubts early on in the war that Ukraine would be able to withstand Russia’s full-scale war, Zelensky said many “simply did not want to take Ukraine into account.” “There was no habit of taking Ukraine into account, although there is a habit of taking Russia into account, even when there is no objective reason to.”
The post Zelensky: ‘The world wasn’t ready for Ukrainian bravery’ appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Zelensky: ‘Russia advancing aggressively in east, we need weapons’
item.description:
In his nightly address, President Zelensky said that while Ukraine’s Armed Forces are resisting Russia’s offensives in the east, in some places Russia outnumbers Ukraine in troops and equipment. “We still need the help of partners, especially weapons for Ukraine. Full help, without exceptions, without restrictions, is enough to win,” Zelensky said.
The post Zelensky: ‘Russia advancing aggressively in east, we need weapons’ appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Despite constant heavy shelling, Sievierodonetsk still accessible
item.description:
Oleksandr Striuk, head of the Sievierodonetsk city military administration, said despite Russia’s constant attacks, the city is not besieged and has enough Ukrainian troops to hold back Russian forces. Striuk said power and communications systems are down and while the roads remain dangerous, “you can get to the city.” He also said there were casualties due to Russia’s attacks on May 25, including two volunteers who died while evacuating.
The post Despite constant heavy shelling, Sievierodonetsk still accessible appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: First Russian soldier to be tried for war crime in Ukraine.
item.description:
The Prosecutor General’s Office said it completed the first investigation of a war crime in Ukraine. The case accusing the Russian commander of the 4th tank division of allegedly killing a 62-year-old resident of Chupakhivka, Sumy Oblast, was sent to court. The suspect is currently under arrest.
The post First Russian soldier to be tried for war crime in Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Investigators find documents implying Russia planned to occupy whole of Ukraine.
item.description:
The State Investigation Bureau reported on May 11 that they found Russian military documents in Trostianets, Sumy Oblast, that imply that Moscow initially planned to occupy the whole of Ukraine. The bureau also identified at least 34 cases of abduction and torture of civilians by Russian troops in Trostianets.
The post Investigators find documents implying Russia planned to occupy whole of Ukraine. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Nine people injured by Russian shelling of Mykolaiv Oblast over the past 24 hours.
item.description:
According to Hanna Zamazieieva, the head of the Mykolaiv Oblast Council, a total of 159 people injured in Russian attacks are currently being treated at Mykolaiv hospitals.
The post Nine people injured by Russian shelling of Mykolaiv Oblast over the past 24 hours. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russian occupiers block natural gas supplies to Luhansk, Donetsk oblasts.
item.description:
According to Serhiy Makogon, the head of Ukraine’s Gas Transmission System Operator, Russian forces have blocked pipelines transporting gas from Russian-occupied areas to Ukrainian-controlled ones.
The post Russian occupiers block natural gas supplies to Luhansk, Donetsk oblasts. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Azov: Russian forces destroyed second underground hospital at Azovstal.
item.description:
Maksym Zhorin, a co-commander of the Azov regiment, told Hromadske media outlet that Russians had destroyed the second underground hospital at Azovstal two days ago, further depriving soldiers of medical care. The same attack also killed 10 people. He added that even those with minor injuries are slowly dying due to poor conditions. According to the government, more than 1,000 Ukrainian soldiers, including hundreds of wounded, remain at Azovstal, a highly fortified steel plant in Mariupol that is being stormed by Russians.
The post Azov: Russian forces destroyed second underground hospital at Azovstal. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Defense Ministry: Ukrainian military can’t break siege of Mariupol at the moment.
item.description:
Deputy Defense Minister Hanna Maliar said during a briefing on May 11 that if there were at least one opportunity to unblock Mariupol, “the country’s leadership would use it.” President Volodymyr Zelensky earlier said that Ukraine needs more heavy weapons to break the city’s siege.
The post Defense Ministry: Ukrainian military can’t break siege of Mariupol at the moment. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Mariupol defenders: All civilians evacuated from Azovstal.
item.description:
On May 9, Donetsk Oblast Governor Pavlo Kyrylenko reported that 100 civilians remained at the Azovstal plant in Mariupol, Donetsk Oblast. On May 11, Azov regiment officer Ilya Samoilenko couldn’t confirm the information about the 100 civilians during an interview with Sky News, saying that “as far as they know,” all civilians had been evacuated from Azovstal. The highly fortified Azovstal steel plant is being stormed by Russian troops.
The post Mariupol defenders: All civilians evacuated from Azovstal. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russian proxies will ask Putin to annex Kherson Oblast.
item.description:
Kirill Stremousov, a leader of the Kremlin’s proxies in Ukraine’s Russian-occupied Kherson Oblast, said there won’t be any referendum in Kherson to make it a so-called “people’s republic”, Russian state news agency RIA Novosti reported. Instead, Russian proxies in Kherson are seeking outright annexation.
The post Russian proxies will ask Putin to annex Kherson Oblast. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Ukraine wins record 103 medals in Summer Deaflympics.
item.description:
Ukrainian athletes have already won a total of 103 medals, including 47 gold, 29 silver, and 27 bronze medals in the 2021 Summer Deaflympics. It is the country’s best-ever result in the Deaflympics, Ukraine’s Ministry of Youth and Sports reported on May 11. The 2021 Games are being held in Caxias Do Sul, Brazil.
The post Ukraine wins record 103 medals in Summer Deaflympics. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: German embassy reopened in Kyiv on May 10.
item.description:
German Ambassador Anka Feldhusen said that she and several other German diplomats had returned to Kyiv to “show the world that we believe in Ukraine’s victory in this terrible war.”
The post German embassy reopened in Kyiv on May 10. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russia fires missile at Zaporizhzhia Oblast, damages infrastructure.
item.description:
Although the Ukrainian air defense destroyed the missile, its fragments severely damaged an infrastructure facility in a settlement in Zaporizhzhia Oblast, the region’s military administration reported on May 11.
The post Russia fires missile at Zaporizhzhia Oblast, damages infrastructure. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: UK Intelligence: Russia tries to reinforce its garrison on Zmiinyi Island.
item.description:
According to the recent intelligence update by the U.K. Defense Ministry, Russia’s current efforts to augment its forces on Zmiinyi Island (Snake Island) in the Black Sea offer Ukraine more opportunities to “engage Russian troops and attrit materiel.” However, if Russia “consolidates its position on Zmiinyi Island with strategic air defense and coastal defense cruise missiles, it could dominate the north-western Black Sea,” the update reads.
The post UK Intelligence: Russia tries to reinforce its garrison on Zmiinyi Island. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: General Staff: 26,350 Russian troops killed since Feb. 24.
item.description:
Ukraine’s Armed Forces said on May 11 that Russia had also lost 1,187 tanks, 2,856 armored fighting vehicles, 528 artillery pieces, 185 multiple launch rocket systems, 87 surface-to-air missiles, 160 helicopters, 199 airplanes, 390 drones, and 12 boats.
The post General Staff: 26,350 Russian troops killed since Feb. 24. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russian missiles hit Sloviansk, Donetsk Oblast.
item.description:
According to Sloviansk Mayor Vadym Lyakh, the missiles hit two districts of the city on May 11. There are no casualties.
The post Russian missiles hit Sloviansk, Donetsk Oblast. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Prosecutors: Russia’s war killed at least 226 children since Feb. 24, injured 417.
item.description:
However, the figures are expected to be higher since they do not include casualties in the areas where hostilities are ongoing and in the Russian-occupied areas, Ukraine’s Prosecutor General’s Office said.
The post Prosecutors: Russia’s war killed at least 226 children since Feb. 24, injured 417. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: UN: 7,172 civilian casualties in Ukraine due to Russia’s war.
item.description:
According to the UN’s human rights agency, as of midnight on May 9, Russia’s war against Ukraine has killed 3,459 civilians and wounded 3,713 since Feb. 24. The agency believes the actual figures are considerably higher. Most of the recorded casualties were caused by the use of explosive weapons with a wide impact area, including shelling from heavy artillery and multiple launch rocket systems.
The post UN: 7,172 civilian casualties in Ukraine due to Russia’s war. appeared first on The Kyiv Independent.

item.title: Russian shelling in Zaporizhzhia kills 1, injures 8.
item.description:
